A short game, but very nice. Tutorial-beginning has just enough explanation of the controls without fully explaining how to do certain things, which makes discovering those things enjoyable. I did the ant section first, which was by far the best section; this order made the beetle area a bit disappointing by comparison, where there wasn't much use of the game's whole gimmick for most of it. It was still *fine*, but I wouldn't have enthusiastically recommended the game to my friends about a third of the way through if that one third had not been the ant area.

I generally enjoy a 2D game with a unique (or at least unusual) mechanic to them, so this was right up my alley. Reminded me of enjoying "Fury of the Furries" way back in the 90s (which was another 2D platformer with 'strings').

Short, cute and pretty fun! Makes you FEEL like spider.
It's sort of amazing how much things you can do with just a simple web mechanic. This is way more than web-slinging, you can practically create your own path anywhere you like with your webs.
Your webs does so much things it's insane, from building bridges, sticking things together, carrying items and even trapping bugs. World wide web.
The game straight up gives you a lot of power using the web right from the get-go, it's really fun to play around.
Aesthetically it's also great, music is pretty boppin and the critters are all so adorable.
The collectibles aren't too much of a chore if you're attentive but the map is a bit confusing. Backtracking for collectibles is a bit annoying too if you're into completioning games, but it's not THAT bad.
Also you can skate. And wear little hats. And there's a dedicated dance button.

150791753.review:
This game is great! 

I love movement games, anything that has a fun and satisfying movement system that you can learn to master is already ahead in my books, and Webbed really nails that in a way I haven't experienced before. It's just so satisfying and enjoyable to whip yourself around pull of some last minute sweet saves. 

That said I think this game struggles in the level design. I LOVE the open world concept, but many times I felt that the level design of each area never really satisfied to the full potential the possibilities of this movement system. That and there are some mechanics that the game never explicitly teaches you, after solving some puzzles I would say "how was I supposed to figure that out" assuming I had just skipped a tutorial somewhere else in the game, even though that was the tutorial. 

Generally this game surprisingly throws you out into the world and expects [I] you [/i] to be creative and figure out how the game works, while I'm generally a fan of this, I think Webbed would benefit from some of the disguised tutorials technique that Nintendo builds so well their games. This aspect never frustrated me however because of how fun the movement system was, I never was too upset to spend a little extra time swinging about, but I suspect that had it not been for that this would have been a frustrating experience, and I think that someone who doesn't groove on the move the same way I do may find this game a bit difficult and and tedious.

Overall I would love to see the mechanics of Webbed pushed and explored further, maybe a "manual" mode that makes the swinging more difficult but with a higher skill ceiling, or a master mode that changes the gravity to be less floaty and slow. How about more time trial challenges that put your swinging precision to the test? A battle that challenges you to put together webs to capture the bad guys, or just exploring each nuance of control that the swinging mechanic gives you in the level design? 

I say all of this knowing that Webbed was put together by a small team of people, and I don't think the game over sells it's expectation in a way that hurts the experience. Webbed feels like it just scratches the surface of what is possible with the adorable, satisfying swinging, and creative collectibles hidden away in secret areas. It leaves me wanting more and that's not a bad thing at all.

Huevo duro, huevo frito, huevo estrellado y tortilla de patatas.

"Desde que me he pasado Huevo no he matado a nadie"
-Señor Anónimo

Cada especie de insecto te enseñará una lección diferente que podrás usar en tu vida diaria:

-Las astutas hormigas comunistas te enseñarán la importancia del trabajo en equipo y que la guerra es divertida siempre y cuando el color de tu oponente sea distinto al tuyo.

-Las gráciles abejas te enseñarán la importancia de la monarquía y que cualquier persona puede ser sobornada siempre y cuando le ofrezcas polen.

-Los asquerosos escarabajos peloteros te enseñarán que hacer bolas con caca y rodarlas colina abajo es divertido, la mierda nunca había sido tan útil.

Un saludo bananero.

Perfect mechanics that deliver exactly what "being an adorable spider" makes you think of.

The game is really fun and unique, at least I don't remember seeing any other game with this kind of gameplay. With the way the spider webs work and the fact that every web you create stays no matter how long ago you made it or how far you went from it really adds a lot to the feeling of creating your own paths through the place. The map helps a lot with completion of the more common collectibles but there are a couple that don't appear there, though between the achievements and the stickers you get some clues to where you can look for them.

Only negative for me is that in a couple of places the game got a little boring and repetitive, maybe some sections being longer than needed or needing something to spice them up, but after getting to new places I forgot all about that and got hooked again. Also, probably a way to fast travel could have helped with going for 100%.

Very short game, got all achievements in around 8 hours. But I have to say, those hours were extremely enjoyable. Some mechanics can be frustrating, like trying to move stuff with your webs (mandibles, gears etc.), but everything goes by so fast that you do not have time to get mad at the little things. 

In terms of movement, you can either carefully weave webs, strategizing your every step, or swing around like Spider-Man (which is what I caught myself doing the most in the latter 4 hours, since it's much faster). The movement is basically the meat and potatoes of the gameplay, so try to have fun with it!

If you want to get all achievements, do not eat the flies before finishing the main story!

Overall, the worst thing about this game is that it ends quickly; I highly recommend it to anyone who is interested in this style.

145017639.review:
This game was an absolute delight, I beat it in ~3 hours (2.7 according to steam), although I didn't 100% it. (I don't enjoy backtracking and looking for tiny little collectibles). I got maybe ~60-70% completion.

Despite being so short, this game was absolutely amazing to play. It's incredibly cute, swinging around as a spider definitely doesn't get old, the puzzles, whilst some could definitely benefit from you knowing minor optimizations (ie you can left click onto an object and drag it with you, instead of what I did at the start, spamming right click webs to EVENTUALLY get the cog in place), none of them are too difficult in concept, the difficulty comes from using the mechanics you have to beat the puzzles. They never felt unfair, they never felt too difficult nor did you really get stuck on them.

Overall, genuine 10/10, I can't think of anything negative about this game. All the specific areas (ants, bees, dung beetles, sky) all ended before they got stale, dung beetle being the weakest imo by far.

Absolutely worth a buy.

This game is an absolute delight! 
Keyboard and mouse controls are excellent! Movement is so fluid and fun. 
There are failure states like thorn walls etc, but the autosave is very forgiving and you don't feel like you lose much progress, plus all your webs stay in place, not affected by your "deaths." 
Music is very nice, although can get a bit samey if you are in one area for a long time, although it also fades away if you are standing still, which is nice. 

All the bugs are so cute, especially the main character. You get stickers if you complete certain objectives and they work like outfits and hats, some also change your web colour. Very cute!

I think even people with arachnophobia can enjoy this, it is simply wonderful.

The bee area is great, just flying around with the tight grappling system. And the beetle area is just a long line that lets you go as fast as possible with the fluid movement.  But then there's the ant place that exposes the web system, which looks really cool but is an extreme gimmick that never should have been used as heavily as it is. Using it to move things around and into a slot just feels tedious and awkward. 

The sound design is perfect, with the webs sounding like guitar strings with increasing pitch depending on how short they are. And the music cutting out when you stand still to set that serene nature mood.

Overall I thought this game is pretty good, but all it has gameplay wise is the solid movement. And finding skate bird was cool. 3/5

143616662.review:
[b] NO SPOILER REVIEW [/b]
What a great wholesome game. I do have a soft-spot for jumping spiders.

The short "tutorial" intro flows seamlessly into the story and the mechanics become very intuitive very quickly, to the point you just want to swing around, shooting grapples, and spinning webs (among other mechanics).
Satisfaction is through the roof. Story took a relaxed 6 hours to play through including completing some of the Achievements/Collectibles.
I see myself replaying this cuz, well, you can imagine how fun it was to role-play a jumping spider.

On another note, the game does feel a bit more catered toward a younger crowd.
I let my kids (starting/beginner-level English readers) play their own save files and it is impressive how interested they are in reading English and how much better they become at it in such a short time. The interactions (conversation texts) are very simple and easy to read, and the game mechanics were easily picked up even by my 5 year old.
The puzzles could be a quite difficult to figure out for little children, and I found myself struggling a bit with navigating a few sections.

8/10

I absolutely loved this game. It's really cute, very well made, is a unique platformer game, and is a perfect casual game for people to play. There's no time limits, there's no unrealistic level completion mechanics, and you can pretty much complete the game in whichever order that you want.

!!Spoilers below!!
[spoiler]Pros:
- Awesome love story between two jumping spiders.
- Very cute insect characters throughout the game.
- Unique antagonist.
- Game physics are really great (it's more amazing that this is a Game Maker game!).
- Amazing hidden features, which I would never have found unless my brother pointed out the locations to me.

Cons:
- The webs can be a bit odd. Webs that become disconnected can show really odd kinks in the web. This applies to even connecting to a bridged web.
- Some game features aren't really explained to you. I think I accidentally skipped a couple of mission points just because I couldn't find what they meant (Find an Ant Guide).
- I guess the game really relies on intuitive thinking to get through a lot of sections (canopy level with all the spikes and the air channels).
- The hidden flies are annoying. Like, you don't indicate where the flies even might be located, so there's really no indication as to where to go. If you're making Easter Eggs, then you shouldn't place required collectables in these locations without some hint as to where they are.[/spoiler]

I'm happy to share my own personal pros and cons, but don't want to spoil anything else about the game. Regardless of my nit picking, I think this is a really great game. I'd easily buy it 5 times over.

143490115.review:
A Webbed Delight! "Webbed" offers a superbly wholesome and relaxing experience that's truly refreshing.

The sheer joy of movement in the game is a standout feature. Swinging around like a spider, crafting nets effortlessly, and the impressive physics make even basic movement an absolute blast. I often found myself spending prolonged moments simply weaving nets and swinging to and fro, an unexpectedly satisfying aspect of the gameplay.

The game's levels are a delight, with a special nod to the sections involving the ants. These segments added a unique flavor to the gameplay that I truly appreciated.

Uncovering secrets tucked away in various corners was an added thrill, adding an extra layer of exploration to the experience.

The open-world style of the game is a masterstroke. It fosters a sense of freedom that melds perfectly with the game's relaxing vibe.

One brilliant touch that stood out was the game's preservation of all crafted nets across the entire map. This small but thoughtful detail contributed to the overall gameplay experience.

While the game maintained its relaxed atmosphere for the most part, the final bird levels did shift the tempo. While they were more intense, they provided an interesting contrast to the overall flow.

In the post-game phase, the ability to spend time with your spider boyfriend or even take them along on adventures is a charming addition that left a smile on my face.

In conclusion, "Webbed" weaves an enchanting web of relaxation, fun, and surprises. Its movement mechanics are an absolute delight, and the game's ability to evoke pure joy from even the simplest actions is commendable. Whether you're swinging through trees or uncovering hidden secrets, "Webbed" is a splendid adventure from start to finish.

143271037.review:
Webbed is an amazing game about a little spider (you) going to save your beautiful boyfriend! You battle birds and make friends while trying bring your home back  to the peaceful place it normally is. 

Graphics - I love the design of this game. Very cute pixel art style. They layer 2d pixel sprite to give them a 3d feel and it works 100%

Sound - This is my least favorite part of the game. Music and sound effects are good, but there are quite a few moments where you have the awkward silence from no music at that moment.

Story - Very simple but works very nicely! It's a simple "recuse the princess" story but this game is an example why that is a timeless trope. Befriend your neighbors and take of the evil bird!

Gameplay - I LOVE IT! I love the web swinging gameplay. Puzzles are simple enough you don't need a walkthrough, but will make you think, especially with the physics. There are also A LOT of secrets locations and items you can collect, rewarding you for exploring. There were a few bugs I ran into, but nothing that was game breaking. (Cursor Drifting while unpaused was the biggest one that bugged me but was fixed if you go fullscreen mode.)
 
Price - For $10 I highly recommend this game for your Steam Library

141861423.review:
Incredibly cute platformer game and artstyle.
I believe the game has been designed incredibly well for the limited amount of stuff you can do. I don't see much of a replay value with this game, however in turn everything you can do is done in a very satisfying manner. The swing physics, web building and even just walking on a surface brings out such satisfaction. I can't praise it enough for how incredibly well-executed just the movement is.
As for the puzzles I can only give my personal opinion on it, but I believe it is very fitting for the casual atmosphere it is bringing. They are difficult enough to make you think how to progress, but nowhere near enough where progress can be lost as it otherwise would ruin the light-hearted style of this game. 141780934.review:
I was hooked as soon I heard the premise, but my playthrough came with some annoyances.

The movement mechanics are top notch. Swinging is objectively fun and you should try this game out for that reason alone. I wish there was more swinging. I want to be Spider-man. Why do I have to stop swinging to do the physics puzzles? Why are there physics puzzles that have nothing to do with movement in the game?

I'm not a fan of the laser; I don't think it should exist, actually. I found it very frustrating to grind my progress to a halt to finagle the physics engine with very limited manipulation ability. I had to resort to moving most of the physics objects with my laser, which felt imprecise and gimmicky compared to swinging effortlessly in other parts of the map.

Also, the escort mission introducing the finale of the game really slowed my playthrough to a crawl. I'm escorting a spider? They are also a spider; why can't they swing after me? Why can't they jump? What could have been a tense moment of the game just ended up being a chore for me.

Don't let this frustration keep you from trying this game out, though. The map is well-organized and beautifully decorated, the characters are cute and sweet, and swinging is fun. The swinging is very fun. :)

141421350.review:
I don't usually like short games (it took me about 5 hours to finish without 100% completion), but [u]I love this game to death[/u], and absolutely recommend it to anybody who loves casual platformers.

It's pretty simple and relatively easy, but there is enough variation and challenge to keep it from being boring. The main challenge, if you attempt it, is finding all of the secrets in hidden rooms [spoiler](the secret spiders, for example)[/spoiler], as they aren't marked on your map, but they're relatively easy to find once you look for them with a guide like [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2795416883]this one[/url] (note this guide has some spoilers for different areas) - but this isn't at all necessary unless you want to experience everything.

---The map [b]shows where you have and haven't collected everything[/b] (at least in the rooms you've been in)! This was incredibly helpful for me. (filled circles are completed areas, unfilled circles are incomplete areas)
--Although I didn't use this feature, there's an [b]arachnophobia mode[/b] where the spiders are turned into little blobs, which only affects the game visually.

---The base mechanic of swinging around with your webs is incredibly fun.
---I didn't encounter any bugs (or, well, I did, but not that kind of bug).
---I think the pixel art style, music, and little sound effects and animations here and there are incredibly charming.

10/10. Instantly one of my favorites. My only problem was that it was pretty short for my standards, but that's probably for the best, haha. Short and sweet.

This game is so cute!! The physics are natural and the controls are easy to get used to (traditional WASD and mouse buttons but intuitive nonetheless). My only gripes are a couple levels' lack of intuitive direction (I'm looking at you Ant forge ._. ) and a couple things in the final boss area. Beyond that, it's very free form and you can go at your own pace and not have to worry about inventory or having to restart too often. There are cute side quests and about 4 hidden stickers I do not know how to complete without looking them up, but by the end of the game I end up wanting more. There's really no other game like this and it quite a unique and fun experience. 

There was a developer's note or something along those lines that I read somewhere that part of the goal is to make spiders seem friendly and more approachable. Unfortunately design-wise that only applied to the peacock spider main duo and every other spider (besides the wolf spider babies, those are so cute and I wish there was a sticker toggle to have them on you like they do with their mom) still freaks me out a bit despite not being scared of spiders. Overall, solid 9/10

It’s a beautifully animated 2d game, has very robust spidery physics, but most of all it’s just pure fun.  More games should be like this! Though perhaps about other topics, not just spiders. This game has that one covered.


It’s a game about being a spider, and you do spider things, like creeping about; jumping; spinning lots of webs for movement and fly-catching; rescuing baby spiders; using leaves as parachutes; shooting lasers from your eyes; helping the ant colony construct their Mecha-Ant by solving a variety of physics puzzles where you drag things around, using your webbing as support, to ultimately forge and construct the Mecha; skateboarding to win stickers; making a stick ‘n’ web suspension bridge that can take the load of two dung beetles whilst wearing a yellow hard hat that the ants gave you for helping build their Mecha; Riding a hot air balloon to the magical cloud in the sky to rescue your boyfriend-spider from the evil bird, and the balloon is constructed from an old moth hive thing that you have to strap to a dung-burning engine provided to you by the ants, all overseen by the princess bee incase you fall off mid-flight.

You know, typical spider stuff.

Also there’s a bug chorus-line for the finale, because that kind of thing is fun.

The cutest and most determined little spider goes on an epic journey around a tree to rescue her himbo boyfriend. (Seriously. When you get to the bit with the boyfriend, he's one of the dumbest NPCs of all. But I say that with love.)

This is a lovely but challenging puzzle platformer, using the extra complexities and possibilities of being a spider to allow you to move around in ways that a human simply could not. I lost track of how many times I laughed in frustration as I accidentally swung into a spiked branch, and let's not talk about how much of my time skateboarding was spent chasing where I had managed to yeet the board itself. But somewhere among struggling with the controls, things suddenly clicked and the world around suddenly looked navigable in all new ways.

Webbed is a delight and a novelty, and I'm always glad to see spiders getting some cute rep out there.

138059242.review:
[h1]Webbed: A few strings short of an excellent net. [/h1]

[b]TL;DR:[/b]
Webbed is a cute, fun, and innovative platformer that is able to accurately translate the movement of a spider into a playable game, creating one of the most unique movement systems I’ve experienced in a 2D platformer, but sadly this unique system is held back by many mundane and avoidable design flaws. 

[hr][/hr]

[b]Review:[/b]

As an (almost) official zoologist, and self-professed invertebrate lover, webbed had a lot to offer me. Although 2D platformers have always and will always be my least favourite gameplay genre, I couldn’t pass up on the ability to play as a spider and interact with other bugs. In this regard, webbed is an overwhelming success: Webbed’s movement is an ingenious combination of blistering swinging and grappling, meticulous bridge placement and the overwhelming feeling that – for the most part – touching the ground is optional. A little rule of thumb I have for judging 2D platformer movement is to watch how speedruns play out, and sure enough the webbed any% is as dizzying as it is impressive. Discovering the wonderful depth of Webbed’s gameplay systems is like tripping into a roadside puddle and discovering an ocean. 

Sadly, the way the rest of Webbed is set up really doesn’t always allow for this gameplay to shine, and in fact, sometimes it feels like the game wasn’t designed around incarnating a spider at all: An inordinate amount of this game expects you to move around heavy objects (notably the infuriatingly bad [spoiler]ant nest[/spoiler] level), sometimes requiring you to meticulously position the object in a location out of your reach. This is a baffling design choice in a game where the main character doesn’t even have fingers, let alone opposable thumbs, and whose closest ability to a “pick up” button is the ability to violently drag an object across level ground. Outside of the frustrating object manipulation sections, webbed has other baffling design decisions: the game’s default cursor, which is more often than not flicked around the screen at high speeds, is a tiny white thing, smaller than a baby spider, that sometimes takes seconds of scrutiny to find, killing the pace of the game. The camera is also awfully stubborn, and a lot of my initial attempts at fast movement were hindered as I was forced to guess where the “webbable” surfaces were. With all of these issues, Webbed stands as a bizarre dichotomy where the engine and mechanics feel completely set up for intense speed, yet the levels feel often designed around precision and scrutiny. Keep in mind with this criticism that this is less a case of a ruined game, and more a case of an incredible amount of wasted potential. 

It wasn’t all bad, though. Some of Webbed’s mechanics sucked, but just as many were smash hits. The section near the end of the game, for example, presented some really unique ideas and made use of parts of webbed I’d always just assumed were gimmicks. Finally, as an environmental science guy, I have to hand it to the developers for putting so much effort in to making an all-too hated group of animals seem so chill. I was impressed with the commitment to make anatomically correct insect designs somehow look cute, and how the game manages to constantly remain wholesome while filled with the sort of creatures we normally impulsively kill running around onscreen. The game made the ingenious choice of copying hollow knight, and using people to voice the insects speaking, which successfully manages to trick us into relating more with the otherwise alien cast of characters. If anything, webbed has hopefully saved the lives of a few hundred spiders, moths, ants and bees, and for that, it has earned my respect. 
 
[h1]4/6[/h1]

137432779.review:
A cute game about a spider using her webs to overcome platforming challenges and help out her fellow insects.

[hr][/hr]
Webbed starts off with your boyfriend being captured by a bird, leading you to go on a quest to try and rescue. You’ll need the help of different insects inhabiting the surrounding forest, leading you to visit three different areas in order to convince them of your cause. Each of these areas is made up mostly of platforming challenges, sprinkling in some minor puzzles you’ll have to solve using your abilities. Overall, all areas felt fair, with each one focussing on a different aspect of the game, making them quite distinct along with their different designs.

The game sometimes feels a bit unfair, when death pits or surfaces you’re meant to grapple lie outside the screen. However, given the quick respawns at well distributed checkpoints, this wasn’t a big issue. Some mechanics the game introduces later on also weren’t immediately obvious to me, but worked fine once I noticed their existence.

Being that you are a spider, said abilities include placing webs in order to connect two points for you to walk between. You can also shoot a thread and use it like a grappling hook, allowing you to swing around. No matter the method, movement feels wonderful, being responsive and fluid while looking physically accurate. Surfaces you can place webs on are often limited, forcing you to get creative with your abilities in order to progress. Your spider can of course also shoot lasers from her eyes, in order to remove webs or different obstacles.

The light narrative is there mostly to guide you through the game, but features rather enjoyable dialogue for the characters you encounter. There are also some side quests, mostly tasking you with finding different collectibles. These, along with some secrets strewn around the map, give some nice incentive for exploring and revisiting areas. Fulfilling most tasks also rewards different spider designs as well as hats for you to equip.

Webbed uses a great looking pixel-perfect art style and features decent music, which even adjusts somewhat, depending on what you’re doing. The game also offers many accessibility options, including settings to replace the spider graphics, remove decorations and adjust the depth of field effect. I also noticed that depending on the game language selected, the title displayed in the menu changes to a (as far as I can tell) creatively localized one, which I found to be a neat little detail.

[hr][/hr]
All in all, Webbed was a lot of fun for me, mostly because of the great feeling movement system and the wholesome vibe the game gives off. I was entertained throughout my time with the game and can only recommend it.

136893677.review:
Tdr: This is a really cute game, and the grappling is really fun, but god it's frustrating to play.

Sorry if this is not well written, I tried my best as this is my first review but there is probably a mistake somewhere.

I really wanted to enjoy this game, I re-played it 2 times to give it a really good chance, but I still came out of it really disappointed and did not like the game that much.

First though, I want to talk about some of the things I did liked.
This game is really cute. This game keeps the realism of the bugs while also somehow making them really cute, even all the spiders are adorable.
The grapple webbing is definitely the most fun part of this game. Flinging around like spiderman felt so cool and satisfying, especially when you're going really fast and get a lot of air time.
The music is also great. I liked all the tracks and I would totally listen to the soundtrack on my own time. Although I feel some tracks felt too short or didn't change much so they got really grating to listen to (But this was probably more of a problem towards how unintentionally long some sections took and not really a fault of the music itself.)

Now... on to the bad stuff...
Moving around heavy items was not fun at all and it made it really hard to tell what the heck you're even supposed to do. What didn't help was placing the webs felt very inconsistent as they kept sticking to spots that I wasn't aiming for. This would be that big of a problem for me if it wasn't for all of the [b]gosh dang physics puzzles![/b] I was expecting the game to be more about the grappling gameplay, but most of the time it's just janky physic puzzles! The ant's area is the most prominent example of this, as there are so many different objects to put in the right place, and you need to do this over and over again though the whole ant's nest! It was so, so tiring...
Another problem I have with the game is it's length. I feel it's too short, as the main story can be quickly completed in under 2-3 hours, and 100% it will only take one extra hour with a guide. The parts that took me the longest was just struggling to move objects to the places they needed to go.

I really wish I could recommend it, as it looks great and playing as a spider was really fun, but its just not worth it with what it offers. I came in with quite high expectations,most because of the overwhelmingly positive score, but it disappointed me greatly. But perhaps that was my fault.
If you still want to play it, go for it I guess, as I would still say there are many things that are fun about this game. But in the end, I personally don't think its really worth it.

p.s. If you're are going to play it anyways then here's a tip with moving the objects: You can use the laser to give a lot of objects a big push, this helped me a lot when dealing with most of the puzzles.

[b]Webbed[/b] es un encantador juego de plataformas en el que asumes el papel de una araña en una misión de rescate para encontrar a su novio, quien ha sido secuestrado por un ave. Para tal tarea, deberás completar una variedad de misiones que requieren ingenio y el uso de las físicas de la tela de araña y movimiento de objetos. Aunque no hay combates directos, la emoción está presente en todo el juego. Además, cuenta con numerosos coleccionables y logros que añaden horas adicionales. 

Los gráficos son agradables y la música se integra de manera armoniosa, acompañando debidamente cada escena. El mapa no es grande, pero contiene suficientes elementos para dar diversidad y mantener el juego fresco. Los controles son precisos, aunque en ocasiones puede resultar frustrante lidiar con las físicas, sobre todo a la hora de tener que mover determinados objetos de gran tamaño. 

Su duración oscila entre 5 a 8 horas totales (depende de los logros), tiempo más que suficiente para cumplir con su argumento y saciar al jugador. Aunque rara vez está en oferta, es posible encontrarlo con un descuento del 25%. Se puede jugar con un gamepad, pero personalmente preferí usar el teclado y ratón para una experiencia más precisa.

136765039.review:
This is a really difficult 'no' to give. 

Personally speaking, it feels like the majority of positive reviews are saying 'cute spider doing cute things', without mentioning the buggy nature of the game itself.

Everything has a physics model to it, for better or for worse, so the number of times I've poked something just to have it launch across the screen and make me have to spend minutes recovering from said poke counts in the dozens.

It crashed on me once, by trying to use a dung beetle as a web target. 

So many puzzles in this are solved by simply 'hoping' that the physics work, while other times you feel like you're doing it correctly, but your 'correct' is wrong, according to the game's physics model. 

The Anthill can seemingly never get you actually softlocked inside of it, but it can make you feel that you might be, and you have to use carefully placed doors in order to actually escape. I spent over thirty minutes trying to find a way out after I accidently flipped a switch to shut the door with me inside of the anthill.

The Bee chapter was incredibly fun, just zipping around the treetops with my web felt great, and I was hoping the entire game would be that. The Dung Beetles were also fairly enjoyable, other than the crash and awkward bridge-crafting. The anthill, however, felt awful to do, start to finish.

It's a fun, cute game that has made me more mad than many other single player games have in years, it severely needs some sort of 'rewind' button.

136487799.review:
If you're looking for a charming and delightful game that will make you smile from ear to ear, look no further than Webbed. From the gorgeous art style to the lovable protagonist, this game has everything you need to brighten up your day.

As a spider, you'll swing through a beautiful world full of vibrant colors and whimsical characters. Along the way, you'll solve puzzles, make friends, and even fall in love. It's a game that's both lighthearted and heartwarming, and it's impossible not to be charmed by it.

One of the things I love most about Webbed is how it encourages you to explore and experiment. You can use your webs to swing from tree to tree, create bridges, and even wrap up enemies. It's a joy to experiment with different web-based solutions to puzzles, and it makes you feel like a true master of your spiderly domain.

But what really sets this game apart is the sense of community it creates. You'll meet all sorts of creatures along the way, and each one has their own unique personality and story to tell. By the end of the game, you'll feel like you're a part of this little world, and it's a feeling that's truly special.

Overall, I can't recommend Webbed enough. It's a game that's sure to put a smile on your face and warm your heart. So why not give it a try? Who knows, you might just fall in love with it like I did.

136408239.review:
Webbed is a cute, beautiful, fun game. 

It most closely reminds me of the game Unmechanical with its side view and physics-based puzzles. However, while Unmechanical was artsy and depressing, Webbed has a far higher degree of levity and beauty in it.
In addition to the now standard features of modern side scrolling platform games of simulating weight of objects, the main new mechanic of Webbed is simulating tension of strings of web. Each web connecting two objects has a degree of tension on it, and joining one web to another or changing the position of the object makes the tension change. It leads to some interesting puzzles, like how best to life a heavy object, and deciding where best to connect the points too.
The game feels extremely polished, like many hours of play testing was done to get it working just right. I've found that puzzle games are especially difficult to get right because there's not really a way to scale difficulty like in other games, so the puzzles must meet the fine line between frustrating and boring for the average person. Portal 1 and 2 did that, which is one of the main draws of those games, and I'm happy to say that in my experience, Webbed got the mix perfect. There were many parts of the game that were hard, and once or twice bordered on frustration. However, the physics engine meant that there were often multiple ways to solve any task in the game, so getting past any point meant thinking logically and figuring out what might work well in each particular situation. I'm also happy to say that not once was I forced to give up and check a walkthrough, and even the hardest puzzles in the game give subtle environmental clues as to how to solve them, so I was able to work through them all and pat myself on the back when I finally found a solution that worked.
Also of note for this game was the interesting setting. The game has creatures with a level of anthropomorphism I can closest relate to The Wind in the Willows. The creatures are physically very similar to their real life counterparts, just with human thoughts and feelings, and a universal animal language. The dung beetles acted mostly like dung beetles, and the bees mostly like bees. The ants, however, have created a dieselpunk level of societal complexity, and their underground colony has electricity, plumbing, and a working forge, meaning they have a full grasp of metallurgy. Your character meets them right after they have repelled a fire ant attack and suffered damage to the colony, and their colony feels suitably broken, dangerous, and claustrophobic. Also of note is the Sky Bower, which isn't just a simple bird's nest, but is a huge imposing fortress studded with magical blue gems that are neutrally buoyant in the air and can make stick doors open and close. These two examples particularly show how the setting uses real animals as the starting point, but this is most certainly a fantasy game, and real life concerns take a back seat to an interesting setting and fun gameplay elements. In particular, in addition to relatively grounded abilities like the ability to shoot unlimited webs and to direct shot webs to connect two distant points, the game gives your spider the ability to shoot energy bolt "lasers" out of her eyes. This is 100% fantasy, but it works from a gameplay perspective, because the energy bolts allows you as a player to precisely sever web strands when they no longer are useful, as well as break through obstacles, and to push things with the blast. It's a stroke of genius that they were included, because the game might have worked without them, but it would have been a slower more frustrating experience if the eye blasts were changed to something more realistic, like requiring to be near a web to sever it. 
All told, this is an excellent game, and I finished it in about 8 hours or so. It has very smooth, polished gameplay, good music, interesting setting, and top-notch, beautiful pixel art.

136238548.review:
This game is absolutely delightful! 

+ The way you move by zipping along by shooting out webs is extremely fun, on its own.
+ There are really good platforming challenges. 
+ Bugs are cute, apparently?!
+ Collectible hunting is fun. You literally hunt for flies. It is very satisfying to ensnare them in your web. 
~ Fair price for the length, but leaves you wanting moooore. 
~ Minimal story, dialogue is so-so. 
- Some of the physics puzzles are frustrating, especially in the ant world. 

Sometimes, it feels like people make a game just to make money, going through the motions of what other games do. Webbed, on the other hand, is clearly made with love, and starts with a unique movement mechanic that leads to a novel, fun experience.

Cute physics puzzle and semi-platforming game. If I'm being real I enjoyed it more than Spider-Man remaster as it has more unique gameplay. It's not really difficult, but it can just be aware they don't spoon feed you how to use the abilities they give you which was a bonus for me - which had me slightly frustrated in the beginning with trying to fling gears into their spots instead of realizing there is a much easier way and having a "Wow, I'm an idiot." moment.

The one issue I have with the game is slowdowns - I've got a good system (32GB, 3800X clocked a 4.1GHz, 3080Ti) and I hit a number of spots where the was lag, likely due to the physics. In the last level it got really, really bad at spots with it crawling. I checked my CPU usage and it was only at 10% so my best guess is it's an engine issue.

132853931.review:
What to say about Webbed... a definite recommend for anyone, even if you're afraid of spiders (there's an option in the settings to turn them into little slimes!)

First off, the visuals. Charming, cute, stylized to hell, and very easy and fun to look at. I've probably spent a solid 2% of my playtime just messing around with the [strike] hat machine (and yes, you get to wear cute little hats) [/strike]. The environments are clearly distinct through a combination of foreground and background textures that easily distinguish areas from one another. This is especially nice considering how it easy it would've been to make all forested areas look the exact same, so kudos to the devs for creating a fun and dynamic environment with continuity, originality, and plenty of secrets to discover.

The writing. Not something you'd fully expect for a game like this, but Webbed has its fair share of characters, big and small. Dialogue is anything but filler, and whether it's solving problems for them or just meeting up with them to see if they have something new to say in each scenario, I look forward to speaking with them. The dialogue is very genuine, characters have a distinct personality in how they speak, and I actually found myself getting attached to all of them and think fondly of them.

Ah yes, the gameplay. Probably the defining characteristic for most games, and Webbed does not disappoint. Where some games with interesting control schemes are designed to be frustrating and unforgiving, Webbed is incredibly accessible, and yet the skill ceiling is higher than you'd think. It feels fantastic to shoot webs, attach them to other objects, and string up a slew of connections to accomplish whatever your heart desires. Movement is absolutely fantastic, and through mastering the swinging mechanic exploration and completion become leagues easier as you fly from screen to screen. The "gimick" sections where movement is changed are a breath of fresh air, often challenging, and greatly contribute to the environment. The best example being the section where it changes up the movement by having you navigate through a bunch of un-webbable surfaces with a tiny leaf that you hold onto and use like a paraglider through winds and thorns. [/strike] Moments like these contribute to the atmosphere of being a little spider having to navigate through often whimsically dangerous circumstances, and overcoming these obstacles is done beautifully, with progress mattering as you get to that next checkpoint.

Overall, it's a great game. My only real criticism is I wish there was more to explore in the form of DLC, but when all you want is more of a game that you've 100%'ed, that speaks volumes to its quality. But yeah, for $10? Get this game, it's more than worth the price.

130944555.review:
An excellent adventure about a she-spider in cartoonish world populated by friendly bugs, saucy arachnids, and one demonic God Bird.  The gamepad controls feel great; it's easy to swing where you wish and plant scaffoldings of sticky, stretchy strands as you please.  Many puzzles can be solved with a variety of solutions -- so I'm pretty certain there are more elegant methods than the tangle of web I usually resorted to, yet I found gumming up the works pretty dang satisfying.  [i]Webbed[/i] is a lovely, laid-back romp for anyone with a yen for adventure in a magnified world and an ounce of patience for open-ended puzzles.

I sure am glad real spiders don't have [b]laser eyes[/b], aren't you?

130323460.review:
I've just finished playing this game for the first time and I think it was very nice. And it was easy enough to get all achievements in one sitting, so my completionist self can be happy for a week. It's a very short game with a very childish story to accompany it- not that it's bad, just that I would probably enjoy it more if I were still 8 years old. That doesn't really matter much at all, actually, since its got plenty of visual charm to make up for it. Jumping spiders are very cute and pixelated jumping spiders are somewhat cuter... maybe because I'm scared of the real deal?

The only thing that I really got to complain about is the mouse pointer, that made shooting webs and swinging about less fun that it could've been, and can get frustrating at parts. Instead of letting me simply click where I wanted to shoot a web and showing me where I could or could not, the game take the position of the mouse relative to the spider and points as far as it can in that direction, even if it's way outside of the web's range. This scheme seems much more fitting to a console controller and not to a mouse. This issue is somewhat mitigated by the game checking if there are multiple surfaces in the same vector, and deciding where to shoot depending on the distance of the pointer. This works suboptimally.

With all thiat said, I recommend Webbed to anyone wanting to enjoy a nice, fun and cutesy family friendly game.
Also I think the ants are communists?

129382404.review:
TLDR: Easy to pick up. Hard to put down.

Graphics: 10/10. No words needed. Just stunning honestly.
Physics: 9/10. It is amazing to swing around and build webs. The main complaint is how difficult it is to pull things and put them in place
Storyline: 8/10. The storyline itself is amazing. I have no complaints there honestly. The main issue is how short it is.
Side storylines: 9/10. I only wish there were more.
Accessible UI: 10/10. No complaints there. Very smooth and easy to use.
Tutorial: 10/10. Once again, no complaints. Easy to understand.
Controls: 10/10. The settings allow near perfect control over the keybinds so you really don't have to worry about that too much. Very smooth.
Accessible Map: 9/10. The only issue is the Sky Bower. Once you've been there you can't go back. Sad.
Final score: 9.38.

This is definitely one of my favorite games yet. The physics are amazing and so smooth. The graphics are just *mwa* chef's kiss, and the storytelling is also just immaculate. The collectible stickers are also very fun. Not going to spoil anything for new players, but some of them are kind of hilariously gamebreaking (iykyk). The colored spiderwebs from the collectible spider stickers are also really cool. There aren't many complaints I have about this game at all. The main thing that I dislike is the fairly short storyline. The only real other things I have a problem with are the lack of post-storyline features. Sure there are side quests etc., but I completed those before I even finished the game, and there is a notable lack of things to do UNLESS you are like me and love making spiderweb art lol. The third thing is that there is no multiplayer function. This game would be amazing with a second person, and I really wish it could be a feature (maybe in the future devs? 🥺). Anyway those things aside I would recommend this game to literally anyone. Get it.

RESUMEN:
Una Arañita que quiere salvar a su Novio (Arañita) Mesclado con la fisica y con el humor, gracias a las cualidades de los insectos. No puede haber nada mejor (En realidad si puede Webbed 2) ,Lo mejor de todo es que, tienes muchas misiones ,fuera de la historia. y dan recompensas para tu Skin de Arañita (Y es para los aracnofobico a si tienes un robot y muchas mas Arañas)

CONCLUCION:
Desde la fantástica premisa mecánica de la que parte Webbed se pueden recorrer muchos caminos, aunque en lugar de explorar a fondo sólo uno de ellos, Sbug Games ha preferido indagar en diferentes maneras de sacarle provecho a esta divertida idea de controlar a una araña capaz tanto de balancearse como de crear caminos, puentes, plataformas y mecanismos con sus telas. Desde intrincados puzles hasta secciones plataformeras, este indie intenta ofrecer una variedad de situaciones a las que su mecánica principal se adapta genial. Su intento por abarcar lo máximo posible puede que le suponga no brillar en ningún apartado específico, pero la sencillez de la que hace gala deja poco espacio a la negatividad y esconde un minucioso y divertido sistema de físicas tras un adorable mundo en miniatura.

I bought this game on sale and after finishing it the first time I felt like this should have been 20€.
The controls are incredibly smooth  if you play with mouse and keyboard. At first, I used the Xbox Controller, which honestly works fine as well, but transitioning to mouse and keyboard for this game was the far better choice.

If you want to get all achievements in just one playthrough then make sure to not eat any flies as this gives you an achievement. 127074008.review:
Webbed absolutely delivers on the promise of "Cute Spider Game"
It's a short and sweet little adventure, that's entirely uncomplicated and makes the most out of its central mechanic

That said, while the gameplay is simple, it isn't shallow;  The game's physics actually allow for some creativity in how you approach solving a puzzle or exploring a new area - there's rarely ever only one correct way to web something up

Speaking of exploring, the movement feels fantastic once you get used to it;  Mastering the web-weaving and swinging all over the place at high speed not only came close to fulfilling my childhood dream of being Spider-Man, but provided me with the most fun I've had with a game in quite a while

Webbed is also very completionist-friendly;  You can unlock everything there is to unlock in just a single playthrough! Not only that, but the game shows you whether or not you've done everything you could have in any given area with green check marks on your map, so you don't have to run around the whole place looking for a missing collectible

All in all, with engaging gameplay, nice sound design, pleasing graphics, fun characters, a surprisingly hype climax, and an undemanding nature, Webbed is a relaxing, bite-sized experience that's definitely worth your time

124135616.review:
The game is short but well worth it. Absolutely brimming with charm and just a delight to play.

The web mechanics are fun, unique, and intuitive, although fine aiming can sometimes be a bit of a struggle and I'm not quite sure why. The cross-hair just seems to go wherever it wants when it should be fairly easy to just fire the web where I'm aiming.

I wasn't expecting the movement to be so heavily momentum based and it was a nice surprise, you can build up an incredible amount of speed swinging around, it's loads of fun, and the environment is well suited to it. I had so much fun with the swinging I forgot you could just bridge around with webs for most of the game. And it's kindof cool that you can just choose which one you prefer to use. My one complaint with the movement is that you can't crawl on walls, and much like the wierdness with the cross-hair I'm not quite sure why. It wouldn't significantly effect the difficulty of the game, you can crawl vertically on webs so the animation is there, and the boyfriend spider as well as the ants seem perfectly capable of doing it. I would understand ceilings might be a bit of a limitation but I don't see why we just can't stick to walls.

Moving objects with webs feels a bit weak. Moving things where you want them often takes 10-20 webs and it can get pretty tedious dragging your mouse back and forth over and over again to preform a simple task. Although it does pad out the play time and for this game that's not necessarily a negative. It certainly looks more web like that way which I suppose is the point. One thing I wish you could do is anchor a web to yourself so you can drag objects around with you while being able to shoot webs at the same time, but it's also fun to work around that limitation.

The way the game is animated kinda makes it feel like a very low stakes rain world and I'm all for it.

Overall, my few nit picks aside, the game is an absolute joy to play and I'd highly recommend it to anyone.

122915130.review:
This game is SO GOOD. It's so refreshing to play a game that has an interesting and unique idea and then executes on it perfectly! Everything in this game is done incredibly well. It's a brilliant experience. I HIGHLY RECOMMEND playing Webbed if it even slightly appeals to you.

If you don't like spiders, play it with the arachnophobia setting on.

The audiovisual elements are wonderful. The visuals are gorgeous, and the animations all interact with the world excellently (very important when you're crawling over objects). The soundtrack isn't expansive but it is a great vibe, gives each region a special feel, and it varies the instruments in the tune as you explore different areas within a region so it doesn't get too samey.

The gameplay is super fun. Figuring out how to solve puzzles efficiently is satisfying. Getting big fast web swings just right and whizzing around the scenery feels incredible. The controls (playing on controller) are executed well, and I especially appreciate the "precision mode" aiming (toggles the right stick from aiming a direction to moving a cursor to aim at - great for the puzzles). The challenge level feels just right - the levels can be quite deadly, but are mostly very forgiving with checkpoints, and while high-skill players can speed through things, casual players can slowly build webs to bridge their way through (which persist forever - saves on tedium re-traversing areas you've been through already).

The story is simple but sweet and enough to drive the game. It's not a large game, but the pacing of the story and the puzzles all feels about right. I don't think the game would be better if it was just bigger and longer. I do appreciate that they made exactly this game perfectly, rather than compromising on some things to add "more features" as is the trend these days. 

But also I would 100% buy an expansion or level pack that brought some new mechanics. A level editor and Steam Workshop support would be killer and give this game some replay value. I would love to play more Webbed, but as it is, re-solving the same puzzles isn't all that exciting.

Both swinging around at top speed and meticulously placing webs to create pathways or shortcuts are incredibly fun, and there's quite a bit of nuance to the movement and webslinging that I just naturally discovered while casually playing through the game.

122130718.review:
[i]Webbed[/i] is a great example of why Steam needs a "neutral" review option. I'm really on the fence about whether or not to recommend it. It's clear that a lot of love has been put into this game, especially in its gorgeous artwork and animations. But that lovingly crafted artwork is let down by the game design, which is mixed at best.

There are some enjoyable parts--the web-slinging feels really good, like a 2D version of the Spider-Man games, except you're playing as an actual spider. I like the mechanic of attaching to a leaf and using it as a glider. I think the movement abilities in this game could have made for a really fun and challenging platformer a là [i]Celeste[/i] or [i]Super Meat Boy[/i], but that potential is mostly unrealized. I'm not sure if this was a deliberate decision to appeal to a more casual audience, or a lack of confidence in level design skills, but it's an unfortunate choice because what we get instead are a lot of tedious, finicky physics puzzles. Actually, calling them puzzles is a bit too generous, because it's always obvious what you need to do; the only challenge is in finding the right way to web things together to get them into the position you need (usually by spamming webs over and over until the objects are pulled together.) The ant quests in particular were extremely unfun and almost caused me to quit the game entirely before I got to the better parts.

If you can slog your way through the annoying physics puzzles, then [i]Webbed[/i] might be worth playing for the fun movement abilities, beautiful visuals, and cute insects. (Personally, I love jumping spiders, but it seems that even people who don't like spiders can enjoy this game. A few reviewers even claim that it cured their aracnophobia, which is great!) But I certainly wouldn't recommend it at full price, and even on sale, I struggle to decide whether the fun parts were worth the tedium and frustration of the ant quests.

I'd love to see the developers make a sequel to [i]Webbed[/i] that focuses more on movement and platforming and much less on physics puzzles. If that ever happens, I'll play it for sure. But I can't recommend the game as it exists today.

PS: [spoiler]I knew Australia had some crazy animals, but it's news to me that their jumping spiders can shoot lasers![/spoiler]

122107092.review:
It's a cute spider game. You go out on an adventure to save your "boyfriend" from a mean bird who stole him away from you.

Puzzles and movement, or controls in general, are a little bit underwhelming and occasionally frustrating due to how webbing in this game works. Which is ironic.

The general gameplay is iffy, and the fact your spider can't even climb on vertical surfaces feels more like a nuisance than a conscious decision to make some puzzles feel more "challenging". Speaking of, the only reason some of the puzzles in this game are difficult is because the game lacks some pretty darn essential controls that would otherwise make this a cake walk. Instead you're trying to figure out a theoratical physics degree in webbing in order to get a god damn cog into a slot.

Webbing, as a form of traversal and momentum, feels downright satisfying to use and I'd go so far as comparing it to the Spider-Man game that just came out on PC; there's enough weight to it that it really makes you feel like you're gaining momentum, but this game rarely ever capitalizes on it and you're mostly restricted to short hops and confusing and aggravating puzzle solving.

Interacting with other insects feels a little odd and breaks the pacing for me. Changing from a cute spider game where you solve puzzles in order to get your lover back (which sounds an awful lot like reverse Meatboy if you ask me), to a cute spider game where literally everybody needs your help is on par with Stray's idea of a story; a creature that has no business doing all the things it does but does it anyway for plot consistencies.

All this is not accounting for the otherwise incredible art direction this game has. It's very pretty and adorable and every area feels unique in its own way, and I have to give credit to the creators for that, but a game that looks good doesn't necessarily mean the game plays good.

I'd like to recommend this game because it's cute and all, but I can't excuse mediocre controls in favor of confusing game design.

This is a game about a cute female spider who swings on webs, grapples around their world, builds spiderwebs to navigate, and solves a global catastrophe.  The gameplay feels smooth, the music is enjoyable, the characters are cute, and the game makes the characters' lives feel important.  It is fun.  How many games today can you say that about?
However, some of the challenges and achievements are needlessly difficult.  If I want to 100% this game, it is going to require a lot more than 7 hours.  A LOT more, in fact.  Currently, I am trying to grind two of them in just one region.  There are three regions to grind in, and I mean GRIND!  That being said, the grind is pleasant for now...
The community is friendly enough, though they and I noticed some unfortunate bugs.  Note: pay attention to which side you fasten the mandibles to.  Failing to fasten them correctly can break your save file.  Developers have not fixed, despite easy solution of preventing the mandibles from fitting on to the one side at all.
Another note: I made my airship with serious sustain.  It was ingenious.  I found a way to carry all the fuel.  Turns out you're only allowed to hold one of them, and they make a totally new airship when you pick it up.  I cannot pimp my ride.  If there is a next time (and there likely will be for that relatively (possibly) easy achievement) I am NOT pimping my ride.  Not worth the effort.
Otherwise, it is a fun game.

A short and sweet platformer where you play as a spider. The mechanics are fantastic and emergent, allowing you to express how you play with them. You can create webs like a spider to walk along or grapple yourself and move hastily.

120707899.review:
I liked this game -- to a point. The premise was appealing and the traversal and physics hooked me in the beginning. After completing the game, I don't think this game had enough legs -- spiders excluded -- to carry this game. Specifically, the novelty of its mechanics, like web spinning and swinging, didn't have enough unique scenarios to make them shine like they deserve. I made it through the whole game despite my gripes.

Positives first: [b]character design[/b]. They got a lot of love from the art team. They made bugs that both looked accurate to their real world counterparts and pleasant to look at in their pixel-style. [b] Second [/b], web spinning. You can definitely just goof off making webs because it's easy to do. This seems to be where the majority of work was spent to make these systems work. Even if it's a little quirky, it works as advertised and I'd like to see more of this physics-based gameplay in other titles. I only wish there were more camera options to see swing-able objects in the environment, especially above and below you. And last, [b] the dancing [/b]. Broadly though, the game is easy-going. You can get in a groove while swinging and spinning. Checkpoints are abound, though disorienting at times. You'll always be quickly back in action when a death occurs. 

[b] The less than positives [/b]: No combat is fine, good even for a game like this. More atmospheric, and less intense. I get it. Some parts of the game, though, just felt empty is all. In its place, the puzzles/physics/world were the focus instead. The three main zones of the world, to me, were far too long and similar to one another. Long corridors with no discernible landmarks and out of view branches/walls to grapple onto were the norm. Cut the long bouts of climbing in half, and nothing is really lost. A shortened game, but tighter overall. [b] Then we get to the puzzles [/b]: lots of awkward object manipulation mixed with climbing + shooting webs in the air. The physics, again, work but they almost work against you as you try to navigate world objects. Some puzzles even have soft-locking potential which is no bueno. No in-game reset button means this is capable of ending people's run before they even get started. 

Webbed made for an above average experience that, without any major incidents, I'd recommend. Even if I think its saddled by some of its shortcomings. I'll be looking for their next title in the meantime.
